headline: EU orders inquiry into £100m contracts awarded without tender
content:
Update on 29 March 2019: Solicitors for IMG have informed The Sunday Times that in January 2019, the European Court of Justice overturned the decision of the Commission. IMG has been found to be an international organisation.

EUROPEAN prosecutors have been asked to scrutinise a consultancy run by a Serbian-based Italian businessman that has been awarded contracts worth hundreds of millions of pounds without public tender.

The European Union’s investigations arm has called on authorities in France and Belgium to look into the International Management Group (IMG), a consultancy that runs projects in crisis zones, for “possible fraud and associated money laundering”.

The consultancy has nothing to do with the New York-based IMG sports group.

An EU report seen by The Sunday Times accuses IMG, which has received almost £100m from the EU in the past two decades, of “possible fraudulent activities including providing the European Commission services with misleading information”.

The group has also won a number of contracts from the Foreign and Commonwealth Office and is at present implementing a £123,000 aid project in Macedonia funded by Britain.

Investigators from Olaf, the EU anti-fraud office, found IMG was not registered as an international organisation or even as a legal company.

For this reason, it argued, the consultancy, which is apparently headquartered in the Serbian capital Belgrade, was not eligible for the funding it has received.

Olaf also claims more than £29m was found in French bank accounts belonging to IMG’s general manager, Dino Bicciato, a former civil engineer from Italy. The organisation denies the accounts were used improperly.

Olaf concluded that IMG, although not a “legal entity”, had secured government contracts in places such as Gaza, Iraq and South Sudan using a crisis situation clause that avoided normal public procurement rules.

The consultancy even allegedly used the address and the logo of a United Nations agency in Geneva to bolster its credibility in documentation.

The investigation was triggered by a tip-off about a conflict of interest in the EU’s agency in Jerusalem. It turned out that two women employed there were married to officials working for IMG — a major contractor in the region.

IMG has already been subject to legal action in Italy, where it was ordered by two separate courts to pay back more than £11m to the country’s foreign service because of financial irregularities connected to aid projects. IMG has appealed against both verdicts.

“We shouldn’t be working with an organisation if we don’t even have clarity about their legal status,” said Inge Graessle, a senior German MEP who chairs the European parliament’s budgetary control committee. “It is illegal to award millions of taxpayer euros to a private person.”

IMG was set up in 1994 as an ad hoc operation to assist diplomatic operations after the civil war in Bosnia and Herzegovina. It now employs more than 300 permanent and temporary workers, including former senior EU officials.

The organisation vehemently denies the charges.

Eric Tonon, a former French diplomat and IMG’s representative to the EU, said investigators had come to erroneous conclusions and disregarded relevant facts.

He claimed there was more than one definition of what constitutes an international organisation and maintained that IMG was eligible for the contracts it had undertaken.

Tonon, who operates from a three-storey townhouse in Brussels, said all accounts containing donor funds were controlled by IMG and subject to the group’s official auditor.

Donors preferred to see the group operate French accounts as it was a country with a “stable financial system” compared with a “transition country” such as Serbia, he said.

Among IMG projects is one for £6.9m, part-funded by Britain, to train police in Burma that includes handing out bicycles to officers.

Tonon said his consultancy was one of the “only” bodies in the country capable of fulfilling the task.

“Why is someone trying to kill one of the few purely European operators in this field?” he said.

A Foreign and Commonwealth Office spokesman said IMG had undergone a formal evaluation by the British embassy in Macedonia and no concerns had been raised.

The group is threatening legal action against the EU. Tonon claimed another branch of the commission has already contradicted the Olaf report.

The commission said the EU would not award new contracts to IMG and it would verify all activities where there were payments pending.

“The commission has taken concrete steps to safeguard EU finances,” a spokesman said.

@bopanc

headline: Where to buy property in Bath, Somerset
content:
“Bath is just so beautiful — it’s easy to take that for granted,” says Helen Chapman. She was a student here and returned to settle permanently in 2010 after ten years in London. “I wanted to live somewhere a bit greener, but still with the cultural side. Here you can walk for ten minutes in one direction and be in the country, and ten minutes in the other and you’re in the centre of the city.”

It’s also a family-friendly city. “There’s a social media thing called Bath Mums, which is a great source of information and support,” says Helen, 40, a consultant and mother to Ella, seven and Molly, three. “And there are so many interesting things to do. For example, I take Molly to an art class at the Holburne Museum. It’s always linked to what’s on, so makes it’s a lot more interesting for us adults than just gluing things together to make a badger.”

Her escape route is a well-trodden one. Thousands of London families have followed her lead, seduced by Bath’s generously proportioned, wall-to-wall honey-coloured Georgian beauty, (slightly) cheaper house prices, excellent schools and convenient rail links from a station that’s easily reached on foot.

The Covid crisis has, if anything, added to its pull. “The family market has bounced back. A lot of buyers, especially from London, had five-year plans to move from the city, which they’ve now brought forward. They want to act now and make a lifestyle change,” says Sam Daniels, an associate at the Bath office of Knight Frank estate agency.

The exodus hasn’t quite returned to the peak levels of early 2018, when more than 40 per cent of homes sold went to buyers based in the capital. Swapping your Victorian terrace in Clapham for a golden townhouse is no longer the financial no-brainer it was, especially if you are going to fork out over £11,000 a year for an annual season ticket, including Tube fares.

You’ll need deep pockets if you want the full Jane Austen experience. Period townhouses start at about £1 million and rise very rapidly from there. Three- and four-bedroom houses just outside the city in Widcombe or Bear Flat (which is slightly cheaper) cost anywhere from £750,000 to just over £1 million. A few flats are available for under £200,000, but to taste even a hint of Bath’s wow factor, you’ll need at least £300,000 for two bedrooms.

Tom Chesher, 40, who runs Ink, a copywriting agency, moved last year with his wife Ingrid and children Max, six, and Matilda, four, into a beautiful three-storey, three-bedroom Georgian townhouse that occupies a lofty perch on Beechen Cliff.

“It was a house we had walked past for years and we always said that we really wanted to live in it one day. From her bedroom, Matilda has one of the best views in the country. Some mornings you can see mist in the valley, and the Royal Crescent spread out below us — it’s heavenly,” he says.

They live in Bear Flat, a short if strenuous uphill walk from the station. Along with Larkhall, Bathwick and Widcombe (home to a top deli and an excellent coffee shop in Mus), it’s one of the villagey “suburbs” that are fast catching up with Lansdown and the city centre at the top of property shopping lists. The Sunday Times chose Bear Flat as one of its best places to live in Britain this year, thanks to its family-friendliness and great sense of community.

Bath isn’t pure paradise. “The only problems with Bath are pollution, overcrowding and getting around,” says Margaret Heath, 88, who lives near the rugby ground. She fears plans to add a permanent stadium as well as cafés, shops and a car park will “make them all worse”. Supporters say it will regenerate a neglected area of the riverside.

The shopping centre can look a bit corporate — and it’s always packed with tourists — but if you look hard enough an appealingly quirky side is emerging, including one of the best vegan food scenes in the UK.

Chesher says the city has improved a lot since he’s been here, and he has seen a new side of life emerge. He says: “There’s still old-school, well-to-do traditional Bath, based around the rugby and real ale pubs such as the Star Inn and the Old Green Tree. But now there’s also a young, vibrant hipster Bath, inspired by the students, with vegan cafés, coffee shops, cocktail bars and boutique gyms.”

headline: How to get glowing skin (just like JLo)
content:
Sound the alarm! Ring the bells! Heck, drop the mic! JLo, aged 51, has teased on Instagram that she is launching her own beauty range. The caption: “Sunset glow… #JLoBeauty coming soon.” The picture: hair scraped back, signature Jenny from the block hoops, a lived-in chocolatey brown smoky eye, a soft nude lip and, for the main event, the most mesmerising bronzed golden luminescence radiating from her cheekbones.

Of course, all the details are locked up till launch. Her publicist will say nothing, so for now our imaginations can run wild. Will it be make-up? Will it be skincare? I’m going to guess a bit of both, but for me, I’m most excited about the idea of using JLo’s bronzers, highlighters and dew drops. After all, if anyone has mastered the art of the perfect glow, it’s her. The pole-dancing, hip-thrusting Latina megastar is renowned for her bronzed goddess, sun-drenched complexion, so I have no doubt that when the time comes, I will be first in line to shop the look. But here’s the catch: she has competition. There are a lot of superb glow-giving products out there.

Let’s start with the new RMS Beauty Living Glow Face + Body Powder (£37). This is a candlelit, refined golden powder that you can delicately dust onto cheekbones, décolletage, shoulders and limbs as the final step of your make-up. It somehow manages to take down excess oil while leaving behind the most gorgeous ethereal skin finish.

Then there is Sensai Glowing Base SPF 10 (£39), which is a creamy liquid packed with soft-focus illuminating pigments. If you’re not a big foundation-wearer, this is all you need each day for that fresh-faced, lit-from-within effect. Otherwise pop it on before your base and you can always dab a bit more onto the cheekbones and browbones afterwards. Sensai, by the way, is a Japanese brand that I often think should be on more people’s radar. The formulas and finishes are of exceptional quality. I often see the make-up artist Mary Greenwell raving about its volumising mascara.

Morphe next. This is an interesting one as I can’t help but associate the brand with the Instagram more-is-more crowd, but each time I try a product, I am increasingly impressed with its wearability. There is a lovely water-based tinted moisturiser in the range called Hint Hint Skin Tint (£16) that I would highly recommend for glowy everyday wear. But the real heroes for me are the Jelly Eye Shimmers (£10). My favourite shades: Woah, a gilded bronze, and Sunshine, a golden peach. They are a treat for sweeping on a radiant translucent pop of colour. Think less sparkle, more sheen. Plus, there’s no fiddling with brushes here — fingers will do just fine.

And finally, I have a preview of one of my favourites launching next month. Dior Backstage Glow Face Palettes (£36) are back, and they’re even better than before with new shades. My top pick is Rose Gold, a vibrant high-vis quad with a spectrum of petal pink tones. I mix and match the shades for cheeks and eyelids, then pat whatever is left onto my chest and shoulders if they’re showing. I get an array of looks out of it; a poppy blush for day and an illuminating highlighter and eyeshadow for evening. A JLo glow? Easy. (Sort of.)

Tweet or Instagram your beauty questions @sarahjossel
label: BEAUTY | #BEAUTYBOSS

headline.value: How to get glowing skin (just like JLo)

content.value:
Sound the alarm! Ring the bells! Heck, drop the mic! JLo, aged 51, has teased on Instagram that she is launching her own beauty range. The caption: “Sunset glow… #JLoBeauty coming soon.” The picture: hair scraped back, signature Jenny from the block hoops, a lived-in chocolatey brown smoky eye, a soft nude lip and, for the main event, the most mesmerising bronzed golden luminescence radiating from her cheekbones.

Of course, all the details are locked up till launch. Her publicist will say nothing, so for now our imaginations can run wild. Will it be make-up? Will it be skincare? I’m going to guess a bit of both, but for me, I’m most excited about the idea of using JLo’s bronzers, highlighters and dew drops. After all, if anyone has mastered the art of the perfect glow, it’s her. The pole-dancing, hip-thrusting Latina megastar is renowned for her bronzed goddess, sun-drenched complexion, so I have no doubt that when the time comes, I will be first in line to shop the look. But here’s the catch: she has competition. There are a lot of superb glow-giving products out there.

Let’s start with the new RMS Beauty Living Glow Face + Body Powder (£37). This is a candlelit, refined golden powder that you can delicately dust onto cheekbones, décolletage, shoulders and limbs as the final step of your make-up. It somehow manages to take down excess oil while leaving behind the most gorgeous ethereal skin finish.

Then there is Sensai Glowing Base SPF 10 (£39), which is a creamy liquid packed with soft-focus illuminating pigments. If you’re not a big foundation-wearer, this is all you need each day for that fresh-faced, lit-from-within effect. Otherwise pop it on before your base and you can always dab a bit more onto the cheekbones and browbones afterwards. Sensai, by the way, is a Japanese brand that I often think should be on more people’s radar. The formulas and finishes are of exceptional quality. I often see the make-up artist Mary Greenwell raving about its volumising mascara.

Morphe next. This is an interesting one as I can’t help but associate the brand with the Instagram more-is-more crowd, but each time I try a product, I am increasingly impressed with its wearability. There is a lovely water-based tinted moisturiser in the range called Hint Hint Skin Tint (£16) that I would highly recommend for glowy everyday wear. But the real heroes for me are the Jelly Eye Shimmers (£10). My favourite shades: Woah, a gilded bronze, and Sunshine, a golden peach. They are a treat for sweeping on a radiant translucent pop of colour. Think less sparkle, more sheen. Plus, there’s no fiddling with brushes here — fingers will do just fine.

And finally, I have a preview of one of my favourites launching next month. Dior Backstage Glow Face Palettes (£36) are back, and they’re even better than before with new shades. My top pick is Rose Gold, a vibrant high-vis quad with a spectrum of petal pink tones. I mix and match the shades for cheeks and eyelids, then pat whatever is left onto my chest and shoulders if they’re showing. I get an array of looks out of it; a poppy blush for day and an illuminating highlighter and eyeshadow for evening. A JLo glow? Easy. (Sort of.)

Tweet or Instagram your beauty questions @sarahjossel

headline: US election Q&A with The Times Washington correspondent
content:
It is a US election like no other, with the candidates having to deal with a pandemic and protests. For Republicans, it’s a chance to show that President Trump can survive impeachment and investigations into Russian collusion; for Democrats, it’s their one chance of curtailing the Trump presidency.

From polling to presidential debates and covering it as a journalist, Henry Zeffman will be answering your questions in a live Q&A. What will be the key factors in determining who gets the keys to the White House come November 3? What can we expect from the final months of campaigning? And what is it like to report on a presidential race that is being run behind facemasks?

Join us for the live Q&A on Thursday, September 10 from 2pm to 3pm. To submit a question in advance, post it in the comments below.

headline: Commuter towns: Deal, Kent
content:
It was HS1 that transformed Deal into the coastal hotspot it is today. Before the first fast train made the 83-minute journey from London St Pancras in 2014, this was a snoozy seaside town that felt a long way from anywhere. Since then, a gentle influx of second-homers and part-time commuters has added a coat of Farrow & Ball gloss, without spoiling the strong sense of community or the Cinque Ports charm to be found in the smugglers’ cottages of Middle Street.

It’s a combination with increasing appeal to city buyers looking to reap the lifestyle benefits they have become used to during lockdown, according to Paul Clarke of the estate agency Mr & Mrs Clarke. “It’s not just a holiday destination, but also a quiet yet easily commutable town. It offers seaside views and value for money — and has managed to modernise while maintaining its character,” he says.

The arty north end has enough galleries to impress the most discerning DFL (down from Londoner). The chichi Rose Hotel is a cocktail bar and restaurant, and there’s state-of-the-art pampering on offer at the Brooklyn Greenspa (run by a genuine Brooklyner). But it’s not wall-to-wall swank. You can follow cod and chips at the Middle Street fish bar with a 99 cone at the Deal Beach Parlour. Excellent restaurants and cafés such as Victuals & Co, Frog and Scot and the Black Douglas are as popular with old-school Dealites as they are with the incoming crowd.

To see the town at its best, visit the Saturday market — happily reopened last month — when the whole town descends on the Union Road car park.

There’s a lot of love for Deal on display, which is one of the reasons it was one of The Sunday Times Best Places to Live 2020. Pub landlords make a real effort with floral displays, community gardeners keep the station blooming and the local environmental group, Deal With It, carries out regular beach cleans. In Kingsdown, a mile or two south along the coast, where mansion-sized houses on the beach go for £1 million-plus, the Zetland Arms has one of the country’s most panoramic beer-garden views.

Simon Backhouse, a director at the estate agency Strutt & Parker, says: “Second-homers head for the conservation area surrounding Middle Street. A two or three-bedroom fisherman’s cottage here can sell from £350,000 up to £800,000, depending on size and proximity to the beach. A cosy cottage might not be big enough for London commuters, in which case next-door Walmer is a better bet.” Even with a price tag of more than £750,000, there’s high demand for three and four-storey townhouses. Beach access and a sight of the sea — and France in the distance — commands a premium.

Need to know

Trains
High-speed trains get to London St Pancras in 83 minutes. Slower trains take more than two hours to Charing Cross. The fastest train to Margate takes 28 minutes, but allow 40 minutes to travel the 20 miles to Canterbury West station. Deal station has 44 parking spaces (£4.70 a day, £792 a year) and Walmer has 43 (£3.10, £504).


Cycling
There are 28 sheltered spaces at Deal station and 12 at Walmer — and there are few more scenic routes to the train than along the seafront, where you can also pick up a morning coffee at Hut 55.


Driving
It’s two hours or so to London and its airports by car, and 20 minutes to Dover, then 15 more to the Channel Tunnel at Folkestone — longer if your journey is interrupted by the grey lady who supposedly haunts the road at Oxney Bottom.


Broadband
Superfast coverage is good, at 96.9 per cent. Full fibre has been scheduled to arrive by the end of the year, but there are no details about which homes will get this first.


Air quality
Concerns about levels by the road junction at Deal Castle.
label: 90 IS THE NEW 60

headline: What’s on TV and radio tonight: Friday, September 18
content:
For full TV listings for the week, see thetimes.co.uk/tvplanner

Viewing guide, by James Jackson

Ratched
Netflix
In 1947 Mildred Ratched starts work as a nurse at a leading psychiatric hospital. But beneath her stylish exterior lurks a growing darkness . . . That’s the pitch for Netflix’s new “origins story” depicting the early years of the icy Nurse Ratched from One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest, played so memorably in the 1975 film by Louise Fletcher. You’ll have to banish memories of crazy Jack Nicholson, however — this is a long way from bleakly realist psychiatric despair. Instead this is a feast of near-ludicrously over-the-top American gothic from Ryan Murphy, the man who gave us Feud: Bette and Joan. Mildred Ratched is like an immaculately lipsticked antiheroine of old Hollywood; once, she might have been played by Joan Crawford, but here it’s Sarah Paulson (The People v OJ Simpson) wearing fabulous 1940s couture and being formidably chilly. Ratched is driven by a dark agenda, but the first episode largely concerns her sly determination to land a nursing job at a California psychiatric hospital, one that looks more like a luxury art deco hotel. That’s because Murphy is in thrall to the sumptuous stylings of that era as melodramatic strings rise and fall in the background. A colour-saturated homage the show may be, but watching the increasingly monstrous Ratched scheme around her bosses, Dr Hanover (Jon Jon Briones) and Nurse Bucket (Judy Davis), in the most twisted office politics you’ll see is great fun — Hitchockian menace dialled up to 11. Just be warned: the lobotomies in episode two should not be watched with dinner.

Jurassic World: Camp Cretaceous
Netflix
The Jurassic Park franchise arrives on the small screen with a computer-animated spin-off, and the only surprise is that it’s taken this long. Otherwise, it’s the usual story: a group of kids enjoying a once-in-a-lifetime trip to Isla Nubar, this time to trial an adventure camp, soon find that various deadly theropods have escaped their habitats. Episode one dawdles a bit with the scene-setting, but rest assured velociraptors are soon baring their teeth. And if it is clearly aimed at younger ones, parents should find it fun enough to watch along with them.

The Romantics and Us with Simon Schama
BBC Two, 9pm
Simon Schama’s erudite series continues by plunging into the human mind. Decades before Freud, the Romantics were the ones exploring the deeper recesses of our psyches. Victor Hugo, exiled in Guernsey, created haunted images of failure while inventing the therapeutic autobiography; meanwhile, the opium-addled poets tested the limits of consciousness centuries before the counterculture. Tonight also features Tobias Menzies reading Coleridge’s Kubla Khan as things get deep.

Soul America: Sweet Love
BBC Four, 9pm
We’ve had religious gospel and countercultural grooves, but for the third and final part of this social history of soul music, things move in a very different direction: the lover-man era when Teddy Pendergrass, Barry White and Luther Vandross gave middle-class couples some sensual sounds to enjoy after dinner. The new sound had its roots in the slow soul of Al Green’s Let’s Stay Together in 1972. Soon, Marvin Gaye had turned away from protest lyrics and put on a bow tie to focus on the bedroom. Candi Staton and Millie Jackson had a more disco approach to this male aphrodisia, and the former’s Young Hearts Run Free still sounds great.

Guy Garvey: From the Vaults 1979
Sky Arts/Now TV, 9pm
Now that Sky Arts is free-to-air, BBC Four has a new rival for Friday-night rock docs, and tonight’s new series offers 60 minutes of pure pop nostalgia as it opens the doors into ITV’s archive in Leeds, home to hundreds of hours of lost musical performances, interviews, poignant last appearances and unforgettable debuts. Tonight, they are all from 1979, including the first ever broadcast of three songs from a previously unseen concert by Kate Bush. Also, Dire Straits, the Pretenders, the Teardrop Explodes and Talking Heads. Buried treasure indeed.

Catch-up TV, by Ben Dowell

When Bob Marley Came to Britain
BBC iPlayer
Imagine Bob Marley playing a lunchtime gig in your grotty school gym and then having a kickabout with you afterwards. This sweet film begins with the Peckham kids who remember an extraordinary day in 1972 that has become emblematic of the fond relationship the great man had with our nation and its people. Marley and his Wailers once roamed the streets of Neasden, played football in Battersea Park and became alarmed at their first sight of snow; his time in the UK was creatively important for him too. He pretty much established himself here, playing two triumphant gigs at the Lyceum Theatre in 1975 and putting reggae firmly on the musical map with a spellbinding appearance on The Old Grey Whistle Test.

Film choice

Terminator: Dark Fate (15, 2019)
Sky Cinema Premiere, 8pm
After 28 years and four blockbuster sequels, this was the first good Terminator movie since Terminator 2: Judgment Day. Gone are the tedious obsessions with the narrative implications of time travel. Gone is the baffling focus on the franchise’s least interesting character, the future messiah John Connor, and gone too are the movies’ seeming inability to use their totemic star, Arnold Schwarzenegger, as anything other than a camp punchline. What the film handsomely mines from the first two episodes is the simple yet apparently elusive combination of momentum and emotional empathy. The returning protagonist Sarah Connor (Linda Hamilton) is in present-day Mexico City where an unstoppable, molten metal humanoid is causing carnage. Only the sweaty and determined Grace (Mackenzie Davis) seems capable of saving the day, with help from Arnie. (128min) Kevin Maher

The Lone Ranger (12, 2013)
BBC One, 10.45pm
The megabucks revamp of the original cross-cultural bromance was panned on release and struggled to find a cinema audience. However, while it’s not perfect, this high-spirited western pastiche is a goofy pleasure. Playing the Native American sidekick Tonto, Johnny Depp recycles most of the eye make-up and performance tics from Jack Sparrow. However, as the lawman turned masked avenger John Reid (aka the Lone Ranger), Armie Hammer is great. He is endearingly clueless when it comes to the whole hero-on-horseback routine. The white stetson, the gung-ho “Hi ho, Silver” battle cry and even the famous mask come in for gentle ridicule. The film was nearly cancelled due to bad weather, wildfires, an outbreak of chickenpox and the accidental death of a crew member. (149min) Wendy Ide

Radio choice, by Debra Craine

Late Junction
Radio 3, 11pm
Radio 3’s late Friday night dose of “experimental music for adventurous listeners” looks at how lockdown may have changed the face of live music. With the Covid-induced closure of venues having led to a proliferation of remote performances, the programme asks whether the thrill of being in the same room as artists can ever be reproduced on an electronic screen at home. Or is streaming the start of a new way of presenting live music? Verity Sharp is joined by Fielding Hope, who runs an arts venue in east London, to discuss how artists have adapted their performances for the virtual world and to look at some of the music that has been created in response.
label: VIEWING GUIDE

headline: Tide starts to turn against China

attributes.value: Oliver Moody, Berlin | Tim Gosling, Prague

content:
Summoning the spirit of John F Kennedy addressing the crowds outside a West Berlin town hall in 1963, Milos Vystrcil proclaimed the Ich bin ein Berliner of the present day.

“I am a Taiwanese,” the president of the Czech senate told the island’s parliament, bringing MPs to their feet in a tempest of applause.

For many years European leaders have hedged their bets on China, mindful of the economic torment their countries might risk if they were to fall foul of Beijing.

Yet the Czech delegation’s trip to Taiwan, a self-governing territory that China aims to bring under its dominion by 2050, crystallised a gradual shift in the EU’s thinking that has been taking place since the start of the pandemic.

Last week Wang Yi, the Chinese foreign minister, visited Rome, the Hague, Oslo, Paris and Berlin to prepare the ground for a summit with President Xi that has now been downgraded to a video conference next week.

Twelve months earlier this tour would have been an exercise in measured cordiality. On almost every stop, however, Mr Wang was confronted with a hardness that sometimes bordered on hostility.

He was chastised for China’s human rights record by President Macron, taken to task on Hong Kong by the Italian foreign minister, and accused of representing an aggressive “new empire” by the EU’s top diplomat, Josep Borell.

Even in Germany, traditionally one of Beijing’s most doveish partners in the region, the welcome was distinctly colder than usual. At a visibly uncomfortable joint press conference with Mr Wang, Heiko Maas, the German foreign minister, urged China to reverse its vicelike restrictions on the Hong Kong opposition without delay and warned it against “threatening” European leaders.

At the other end of the world, nearly 6,000 miles away, Mr Vystrcil and his colleagues were engaged in an act of audacious provocation.

In defiance of Beijing and their own government, the Czech politicians paid an official visit to Taiwan, which has been diplomatically isolated for decades and now faces a build-up of overwhelming military force on the Chinese mainland.

Chinese state media denounced Mr Vystrcil as a “political hooligan” who had “trampled on diplomatic civilisation”. Mr Wang said that there would be a “heavy price” to pay for the insult.

Yet Zdenek Hrib, the liberal mayor of Prague, who accompanied Mr Vystrcil and enraged China by twinning his city with Taipei, told The Times that the trip demonstrated that China had “little means” of punishing foreign states that ignored its threats.

“The world is seeing that China can do little to hurt the Czech Republic,” he said. “Everyone can now see that Beijing does not fulfil its promises and is an unreliable partner.

“I believe the net result will be positive for the Czech Republic. Taiwan is a much better partner. It’s a technologically advanced democratic state. China, a communist dictatorship, has promised lots but delivered little.”

No one would bet on larger European nations following suit. Back in Prague, the pro-Chinese President Zeman has dismissed the delegation as a “boyish” escapade, and Czech foreign ministry officials complain that it has complicated their jobs.

But both Germany and France have declared their solidarity with the Czechs and there is a strong sense of a sea change in the European Union’s China policy.

Beijing’s increasingly strident “wolf-warrior” diplomacy, its economic empire-building and evasiveness on the origins of the Covid-19 pandemic have begun to disconcert European diplomats.

The persecution of the Uighur minority in the western province of Xinjiang and the iron-fisted suppression of the Hong Kong protest movement are regarded as part of a broader pattern that is now too blatant to ignore.

Public opinion is also turning: one recent survey found that opinions of China had deteriorated drastically in Spain, France, Italy and Germany since the advent of coronavirus.

Noah Barkin, a senior visiting fellow at the German Marshall Fund in Berlin, said that a French diplomat had told him that a new approach to China was emerging.

“For quite a while, we looked at all of the China issues, whether it was trade, Hong Kong, 5G, or the South China Sea, as distinct issues,” the diplomat is reported to have said. “Now there is a recognition that compartmentalising is no longer adequate, that we need a comprehensive strategy.”

Last week Chancellor Merkel’s cabinet announced its own Obama-style pivot towards Asia, building stronger ties with countries such as Japan, India and Australia and increasing its naval presence in the western Pacific.

In response to an intense lobbying campaign by the United States, European countries are also slowly shutting Huawei, a market-leading Chinese telecoms company with murky links to Beijing, out of their new high-speed mobile phone networks.

The EU is still very far from unambiguously picking a side in the pitched battle between the US and China.

Beijing retains a great deal of influence over parts of central Europe and is spending billions on a high-speed railway that will ultimately run from Piraeus, a Chinese-owned port near Athens, to Budapest via Macedonia and Serbia. The objective is to extend the “Belt and Road” trade network deep into the heart of the Continent.

Officially, too, German ministers continue to recite the well-worn aphorism Wandel durch Handel (change through trade) whenever they are asked about China.

Yet the change of tone is palpable. As the customarily mild-mannered Mr Maas told his Chinese counterpart in Berlin: “At the moment I am trying to make it clear to everyone I talk to . . . that they must brace themselves for Europe to represent its interests more confidently. We will not allow ourselves to become a political football in the great-power rivalry between the US, Russia and China.”
